Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Octahedral Control of Electronic Properties in Semiconducting Perovskite Heterostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The ability to design and control the atomic structure of materials in order to achieve a desired macroscopic property is a grand challenge of materials research. The complex oxides are an ideal family of compounds for addressing this challenge due to their ubiquity, societal importance, and strong dependence of structure on properties. For instance, properties including magnetism, ferroelectricity, catalytic behavior, and electronic conductivity are known to couple directly to atomic structure in oxides. This project aims to stabilize complex oxide thin films in non-equilibrium atomic structures in order to control electronic properties relevant to applications ranging from solar energy conversion to optoelectronics. Outreach and educational activities, with particular emphasis on the importance of structure/property relationships in materials, are incorporated in the project.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The goal of the project is to control electronic properties such as the band gap and carrier mobilities in semiconducting perovskite films by enforcing non-equilibrium atomic structures. While a dominant theme in oxide research has been to develop an understanding of interfacial charge transfer, the use of interfaces to finely tune local structure and bonding environments has yet to be fully explored as a means to control physical properties. In ABO3 perovskites, the distortions and rotations of the corner-connected BO6 octahedra, which determine the B-O bond lengths and B-O-B angles, are known to couple directly to electronic structure. While approaches to control octahedral behavior in bulk perovskites are limited to compositional changes, oxide heterostructures offer new routes to engineering octahedral behavior independent of composition. In this project, local atomic structure in isocompositional perovskite films is systematically varied via strain or substrate-film coupling. Structural and electronic properties are probed using a combination of synchrotron diffraction, spectroscopy, and electronic transport measurements. By directly comparing octahedral behavior and electronic properties, the project isolates structure as a single independent variable and provides a direct study of how mobility and band gap can be controlled by the local bond environment. The fundamental insights gained into these atomic structure/electronic properties relationships can be used to guide materials design for applications in energy conversion and oxide electronics. The participating graduate and undergraduate students receive hands-on training with advanced materials synthesis and characterization techniques, including molecular beam epitaxy and synchrotron-based scattering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Professor Steven May at Drexel University recently completed research for award DMR-1151649, studying how to stabilize non-equilibrium atomic structures in semiconducting ABO3 perovskite films in order to gain enhanced control over their functional properties. A key feature of perovskite oxides is that the B-O-B bond angles, which deviate from 180° due to rotations of the BO6 octahedra, are directly coupled to their electronic, optical, and magnetic properties. In metal oxide thin films, these bond angles can differ significantly from their bulk counterpoints due to both substrate-induced strain and structural coupling across interfaces, thus leading to different properties in films compared to bulk materials. This project has made significant contributions to the understanding of how to control octahedral rotations in oxide heterostructures and how to use these rotations to tune semiconducting properties. 

The PI’s group has grown high-quality thin films and superlattices of EuFeO3, LaFeO3, SrFeO2.5, CaFeO2.5, and LaMnO3 and their alloys using molecular beam epitaxy. The project has made significant contributions to understanding octahedral rotations in these and other perovskite thin films. The PI’s group has determined what factors play the most important roles in stabilizing particular patterns of octahedral rotations in orthorhombic perovskite films. In work carried out in collaboration with Penn State University, the PI has developed a refinement method to quantify B-O-B bond angles in perovskite oxide thin films, even in the presence of other common structural distortions. A second major area of contribution from the project is in deepening the understanding of optical absorption in semiconducting perovskite films. Working in collaboration with the group of Professor James Rondinelli at Northwestern University, the PI’s group developed a method to model optical absorption spectra to accurately determine band gaps in complex metal oxides. The PI’s group illustrated how changes to the Fe-O-Fe bond angles alter the optical absorption in ferrite films. The PI’s group also demonstrated how ordering of oxygen vacancies and cations in (CaFeO2.5)n/(SrFeO2.5)n superlattices can be used to make new layered polar materials, thus potentially adding new functionality such as non-linear optical behavior or the bulk photovoltaic effect to these materials. In total, this project has resulted in more detailed understanding of how to control local atomic structure in metal oxide films and exploit this control to engineer properties of interest for electronic and optoelectronic applications.

Research results from this grant have been disseminated in 9 publications in peer-reviewed journals.  Research was presented at numerous national and international conferences and departmental seminars, including 13 invited talks by the PI and 5 contributed presentations by graduate students. This grant provided at least partial support for the education and training of four PhD students and one MS student. Three of these PhD students now work on semiconductor heterostructures at Micron Technologies and Intel; the fourth PhD student is a postdoctoral researcher at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. As part of this project, the PI carried out educational outreach activities for high school students including advising them on research projects for regional science fair competitions and giving presentations and demonstrations at local high schools. Due in large part to these outreach activities, the PI received the 2015 Bradley Stoughton Award for Young Teachers from ASM International for outstanding teaching/mentoring in materials science and engineering to an individual under the age of 35.
